headline: John Terry auctioning two infamous Chelsea shirts and Man Utd fans will love one
body: John Terry is auctioning the kit he wore during his infamous penalty slip and miss in the 2008 Champions League Final against Manchester United. The former Chelsea captain is clearing out his wardrobe of some iconic pieces of memorabilia in order to raise money for charity.

In addition to the strip from that notorious moment, a more difficult goodbye may come as he parts ways with the kit which he wore when lifting the 2011/12 Champions League trophy. Terry was in his full Blues kit despite being suspended for the penalty shootout win itself.

While Chelsea fans may be queuing up for a Champions League-winning top, perhaps there will be some United fans in search of the grass stains left in Terry's 2008 shirt after his slip. After being called upon to take the decisive penalty following Cristiano Ronaldo's miss, Terry slipped as he hit the ball and struck the post in Moscow. The Red Devils went on to win in sudden death.

The bidding will begin at $5,000 (£3,700) for that shirt. Others have a cheaper entry with the tops from the final game of his Chelsea career and his last career match listed at $1,000 (£740). They are among more than 20 items that the 45-year-old is putting up for auction with proceeds going to charity.

The funds will be directed to the John Terry Foundation, which supports a range of charities nationwide. "My foundation is going to benefit with two very close to my heart foundations that are in desperate need of the money," Terry said. "It's going to a great cause, so all the support is going to be welcome."
More high-ticket items will also be available. Terry is also set to let go of his first Premier League winners' medal.
The Chelsea icon captained his team to a dominant title win under Jose Mourinho, ending the club's 50-year wait for the title. The medal could raise up to £75,000.
Shirts that Terry has claimed in some of his biggest battles will also be available. Match-worn tops from Thierry Henry, Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi will all go under the hammer.
The sale will take place on Wednesday, December 31 via an online auction house, Goldin. A spokesperson said that the collection was a testament to Terry's truly 'remarkable' career.

"When considering the greatest defenders in the history of English football, John Terry's name can often be found at the forefront of the conversation," a statement read. "A stalwart and imposing presence on Chelsea's vaunted back line, a position he held with the club for nearly 20 years, Terry quickly was anointed as the club's skipper under newly arrived manager Jose Mourinho, a decision that proved wise beyond measure.
"Among the lots is Terry's Premier League medal from his first win in 2004-05 and some of the shirts exchanged with opponents, including Lionel Messi

"In addition to his domestic achievements, Terry established himself as an accomplished lynchpin on the backline of England's National Team, appearing in 78 international competitions while representing the Three Lions and scoring six goals total.
"Goldin is proud to present a remarkable array of memorabilia sourced directly from John Terry's personal collection, testaments to various stages of Terry's illustrious and accomplished career."

headline: Marcus Rashford discovers transfer fate as Barcelona decision comes to light
body: Marcus Rashford has been a hit during his Barcelona loan spell - and the majority of the Catalan club's fans want the club to sign the Manchester United man permanently next summer according to a vote held by a Spanish outlet.

Rashford joined the La Liga giants in the summer, with United and Barca agreeing to a deal that includes an option for Barca to sign him permanently at the end of the season. The Spanish giants will have to pay around £26million to keep Rashford in Catalonia beyond May 2026.

The 28-year-old has scored seven goals and provided 11 assists in 24 appearances under Hansi Flick. Such form has placed him in contention for an England call-up for the World Cup next summer Flick, according to reports in Spain, wants to retain Rashford's services, and the club are actively working towards a deal.

Mundo Deportivo hosted a poll which revealed 54.6 per cent of Barca fans would be in favour of keeping Rashford at the club, by activating the purchase option in his loan. A total of 6.3 per cent reckon that sporting chief Deco should hold off until the end of their season.
That leaves almost 40 per cent of fans in opposition to signing Rashford permanently.

For his part, Rashford appears content at Camp Nou. The Manchester United academy product has discussed his future ambitions with the club. He told SPORT in an interview: "I'm adapting very well to the club and the city. From the moment I arrived, I felt that everyone welcomed me very well.

"For me, the reason I'm here is to help the team win trophies. Last season was fantastic, but in life, everything happens very quickly, things change, and the goal is to repeat the successes. I'm totally focused on this.

"With the staff and the teammates, everything is fantastic, I can't complain. Of course, what I want is to stay at Barca. It's an end goal, but it's not the reason why I'm training hard and giving it my best.
"The purpose is to win. Barca is a huge, fantastic club, built to win titles."

With time off this Christmas, during La Liga's winter break, Rashford delivered presents to children at two Barcelona Foundation centres. The forward explained: “I grew up in this type of environment.
“I always knew from a young age that if I was ever in a position or situation to help [I would], especially people that I see myself in.
“It’s very important. We have to understand as much as we can from them because they are the future of everything If we can give them the best opportunities, it’s the right thing to do.”

headline: Bruno Fernandes sends message to Man Utd forgotten star after Ruben Amorim U-turn
body: Manchester United captain Bruno Fernandes has offered words of encouragement to Tyrell Malacia following the full-back's first outing for the club since the beginning of the year. Malacia entered the pitch as a substitute during United's 1-0 Boxing Day victory against Newcastle United.

He came on for Luke Shaw in the 88th minute and assisted Ruben Amorim's team in securing crucial three points, drawing them level with Chelsea in fifth place. The left-back had spent the latter part of last season on loan at PSV Eindhoven after failing to impress Amorim.

Despite appearing destined for a summer departure, he has since been brought back into the United fold. Following six consecutive matches on the substitutes' bench, Malacia finally made his comeback at Old Trafford against Newcastle.

On social media, Malacia shared several photographs from the match, accompanying them with the biblical verse Romans 8:18, which states: "For I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory that is to be revealed to us."

Bryan Mbeumo, Amad, Rasmus Hojlund, Joshua Zirkzee, Matthijs de Ligt, Harry Maguire, Senne Lammens, Altay Bayindir, Diogo Dalot and Leny Yoro all showed their support by liking the post. Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Antony also chimed in with comments on Malacia's post, as did international teammates Ian Maatsen and Justin Kluivert.
United's manager, Amorim, has previously commended Malacia's determination to regain his place in the team. "I love all my players," he declared back in October.
"I demand the same thing from all my players.

"He is working really well, he adapted really well to our team. For me, there are no favourites. If you work, you play for Manchester United. If you don't, you need to work harder to get back on the pitch."

With the January transfer window just around the corner, Malacia is expected to be a hot topic of conversation. Previous loan deals to Elche and Eyupspor fell through last summer before he was reintegrated into the squad.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo 'considering permanent Man Utd exit' despite fresh Ruben Amorim claim
body: Kobbie Mainoo has, for the first time, been considering leaving Manchester United on a permanent basis, a new report claims. Mainoo, 20, has been left disgruntled by his lack of game time under Ruben Amorim.

The midfielder's only start this season came in United's humiliating Carabao Cup loss to Grimsby Town in August. Mainoo pushed to leave his boyhood club on loan towards the end of the summer transfer window, but the Red Devils weren't willing to let him go.

Amorim was set to turn to Mainoo for United's game at Aston Villa last Sunday before he suffered an injury in training. The calf problem also ruled him out of Friday's hard-fought 1-0 win at home to Newcastle.

With just a few days until the January window opens, it's emerged that Mainoo is once again weighing up a departure - but this time not on loan. The i Paper report that sources close to the 10-time England international say that he's been exploring a permanent exit, with a number of clubs across Europe registering their interest.
Napoli could be one of them. Former Old Trafford team-mates Scott McTominay and Rasmus Hojlund have reignited their careers in Naples, and Mainoo has been tipped to be next.

United, however, would only entertain a huge offer and are lacking depth in midfield. Bruno Fernandes is currently out injured and Casemiro has only played 90 minutes three times for United this season.

Unless the Red Devils were able to sign one of their top midfield targets - Elliot Anderson, Carlos Baleba or Adam Wharton - selling Mainoo would leave Amorim with only Mason Mount and Manuel Ugarte as backups to Fernandes and Casemiro. Ugarte has started United's last two games while Mount picked up an injury on Boxing Day.

Before beating Newcastle, Amorim said that Mainoo was the club's 'future', appearing to rule out a January exit. "That is my feeling," the Red Devils boss said. "He just needs to wait for his chance and everything can change in football in two days."

Amorim went on to say: "If we are not getting someone, it is hard to leave. Even with a full squad we are shorter [in terms of players] for something that can happen here so it's going to be hard for someone to leave the club if we don't get a substitution."

headline: Jadon Sancho impresses Wayne Rooney with Aston Villa cameo against former club Chelsea
body: Wayne Rooney has shared his admiration for Jadon Sancho's brief appearance for Aston Villa. Sancho made a move from Manchester United to join Villa on loan for the rest of the season during the summer transfer window.

Villa faced Chelsea in the Premier League on Saturday night, where Sancho was given an opportunity to play against his former team from the bench, having spent the previous season on loan at Stamford Bridge.
Chelsea had the chance to sign Sancho permanently from United in the summer, with a £25million obligation to buy clause included in the loan deal.
However, the London club chose not to activate the clause and instead paid a penalty fee to United, resulting in Sancho returning to Old Trafford.
Before making a cameo appearance against Chelsea on Saturday night, Sancho had only played 13 games for Villa.
Due to loan rules that prevent players from competing against their parent clubs, the 25-year-old was unable to play against United last week.
Rooney has expressed his admiration for Sancho's performance off the bench for Villa, noting the forward's limited game time this season.
"Jadon Sancho came into this as well, and we haven't seen much of him this season, but I thought he was excellent when he came on," Rooney said on BBC's Match of the Day.
"Getting the ball, driving with the ball and committing the Chelsea defenders and then they had runners, they had Morgan Rogers making runs in behind."
Sancho's future at United remains uncertain, with his contract at Old Trafford due to expire next summer.

United do have the option to extend the deal by an additional 12 months if they choose, potentially allowing them to secure a fee for Sancho in the summer rather than risk losing the ex-Borussia Dortmund star on a free transfer.
Sancho's next chance to shine for Villa will be in their upcoming match against Premier League leaders Arsenal at the Emirates Stadium on Tuesday night, their final game before the New Year.

headline: Man Utd star makes decision on quitting England for rivals ahead of World Cup
body: Manchester United youngster Ayden Heaven will NOT switch his international allegiance to play in next summer's World Cup despite being eligible to play for Ghana.

The 19-year-old London-born defender qualifies to represent the Black Stars through a grandparent and the Ghanaian FA have been monitoring his development. Intriguingly, Ghana, along with Panama and Croatia, are in England's World Cup group in the United States, meaning Heaven could theoretically play against England next summer.

However, BBC Sport say Heaven will not be taking to the field for the African nation and harbours ambitions of playing for the senior England team after representing them at under-18, 19, and 20 levels.

After joining United just under a year ago, Heaven secured his place in Ruben Amorim's first team squad this season. The central defender has spent a great deal of time among United's substitutes but has become a fixture of the starting XI in December.
He said: "It was [big]- finally a clean sheet. We've been waiting for this for a couple of weeks. I'm just so happy. I'm so thankful for everyone who helped us [win].

"As Manchester United, we belong in Europe, and we want to get back there next season. We can push for the top four, possibly push for the league; anything is possible. We are just going to keep trying.
"The manager, we play loads of formations with him, whatever he does, we know it's going to work, you saw today. I'm so proud of the team."
Manager Amorim has been impressed with Heaven's development. The youngster started the month being substituted at half-time against West Ham before putting together a strong run.
"I am really pleased with Ayden," Amorim said. "You can feel that he is improving every game. He is young, but you can feel that he has a good game, slows the thinking and improves during the game.
"He trained really well and, if he continues to play like that, it is going to be really hard to take his place."

headline: Man City, Liverpool and Man Utd learn what Antoine Semenyo wants ‘rapidly’ amid transfer date
body: Manchester City have been informed why Antoine Semenyo is eager to join their ranks as soon as the January transfer window swings open. The Bournemouth ace has been strongly linked with a move to City in the New Year.
Semenyo's future has been a topic of discussion in recent months, with numerous clubs reportedly vying for his signature.
Manchester United, Liverpool and Chelsea have all been mentioned as a potential destination for Semenyo, but City have surged ahead as the favourites in recent days.
BBC Sport reporter Sami Mokbel has explained why City are leading the race to sign Semenyo, and why the player is keen to make the switch to the Etihad Stadium at the earliest opportunity.

"I think this one has got the potential to be the biggest, certainly financially, of the January transfer window," Mokbel said on Football Focus. "There are two conditions that need to be met: a £65million release clause which needs to be triggered by January 10.
"At the moment, Manchester City are in pole position and every indication that we've had so far leading up to today has been that he will go there.
"Bournemouth are quite keen for him to stay until January 10, they've got games against Brentford, Chelsea, Tottenham and Arsenal.
"But my understanding is Semenyo wants this deal done rapidly and he wants to move to Manchester City, basically on January 1.
"So every indication we've got at the moment is that he'll be at the Etihad."
Bournemouth manager Andoni Iraola was quizzed about Semenyo's future following their 4-1 hammering by Brentford on Saturday.
"No, the more games Antoine can play for us, (the better)," Iraola said when asked if he would want Semenyo's exit wrapped up early in January.
"If he can play years for us, it's much better! If it cannot be years, it can be months. If he can only play weeks, it is weeks but the more time he plays with us, the better for us.
"Antoine's situation is quite clear. Antoine is a massive player for us and even in games like today where probably he hasn’t played well, he is always a threat to score and assist.

"Obviously I don't want to lose him. This is quite clear, but there are some situations that are not under my control. He will be available to play again in three days [versus Chelsea] and then the next one and I hope he plays a lot more with us."

headline: Bruno Fernandes made his feelings clear as former player targeted for transfer return
body: Manchester United's Bruno Fernandes has already approved a transfer target identified by Ruben Amorim, as the Red Devils consider bringing back a former player in the upcoming January transfer window.

United are said to be keen on re-signing Everton midfielder James Garner. Other potential targets include Nottingham Forest's England international Elliot Anderson, who has been performing well this season. However, according to the Daily Mail, Garner is moving up the priority list and already has the backing of captain Fernandes.
Significant changes are expected in United's midfield over the next two transfer windows, with Casemiro, Fernandes, Toby Collyer, Manuel Ugarte and Kobbie Mainoo all rumoured to be on their way out.

Despite future plans, United are currently short of options in midfield, with centre-back Lisandro Martinez recently filling in off the bench against Aston Villa. Injuries to Fernandes and Mainoo mean that Amorim will likely delve into the January transfer market for reinforcements.
Garner, whose contract with Everton expires in the summer, could be a savvy signing for United. He spent four years at the club, although much of his time was spent out on loan.
Everton are attempting to negotiate a new contract for Garner, who has impressed at the Hill Dickinson Stadium, but it's understood that United may try to secure his services in January.
It's now emerged that captain Fernandes holds Garner in high regard and you'd expect the Portuguese star would be eager to see the Birkenhead-born midfielder make his way back to Old Trafford.
During an exclusive Q&A on the Manchester United website in 2021, Fernandes discussed how much the academy graduates had impressed him throughout pre-season.
"I think we know some of them already," Fernandes explained. "Jimmy Garner, I think is a really good player, I really like him and the way he kicks the ball.

"He's really aggressive off the ball too. [Anthony] Elanga was already playing with us and this pre-season he has been brilliant. He's a nice kid, works hard and is really humble and I think he's deserving of everything that's happening to him. I see a brilliant future for him and Jimmy too, and also for all the other kids."
When asked by a supporter on X in 2022 which academy prospect he was most excited about potentially playing alongside, Fernandes singled out Garner.

headline: Christian Eriksen makes Ruben Amorim claim after 'worst Man Utd' admission
body: Christian Eriksen has taken aim at Ruben Amorim's claim that last season's Manchester United team was "maybe the worst in history". The Danish star has revealed the dressing room reaction to the comments, admitting that they hindered the team's morale.

The former Sporting CP boss made the statement in January after a 3-1 loss to Brighton and Hove Albion. This marked their fourth defeat in five home games, and a meagre haul of 11 points since Amorim took over from Erik ten Hag.

This season, United have bounced back and are vying for a European spot, sitting just three points shy of the top four following their 1-0 victory over Newcastle United on Boxing Day. This is a significant step up from last season's performance, where they ended up 15th in the Premier League and suffered a loss in the Europa League final to Tottenham Hotspur.
Eriksen feels that the public criticism of the team only added to the pressure on the players during an already challenging campaign.
Speaking to The Times, he said: "That didn't help. Yeah, that didn't help at all. I mean, that was not... I don't think that helped the players at all.
"Some stuff you can say inside and it's not too clever to say outside, to put extra pressure and put an extra label on the players who were already trying to do their best.
"I don't think that helped at all, no. Then if he's right or wrong, whatever, but I think for us it was a bit of like, 'Oh, here we go again. Another headline.'"

Amorim's remarks followed a disappointing display against the Seagulls at Old Trafford in mid-January. Bruno Fernandes managed to equalise, but the suffering persisted as Kaoru Mitoma and Georginio Rutter compounded their woes.

The United boss has come under fire for his side's displays this season, but last term it was the players who bore the brunt of criticism after struggling to reverse their fortunes despite a managerial change.
Amorim made waves with his assessment when he branded his squad as "maybe the worst" in the club's 147-year existence.
He said: "In [the past] 10 games in Premier League, we won two. Imagine what this is for a fan of Manchester United. Imagine what this is for me.
"We are getting a new coach who is losing more than the last coach. I have full knowledge of that.

"We are the worst team maybe in the history of Manchester United. I know you [media] want headlines but I am saying that because we have to acknowledge that and to change that. Here you go: your headlines."
Eriksen's deal at Old Trafford ran out in the summer before he joined Wolfsburg on a free transfer.

He featured 22 times under Amorim during his 107 matches at United, netting once. Fifteen of those appearances came in the Premier League, though he was named in the starting XI on just six occasions.
Eriksen said: "Yeah, he came in with his ideas. He tried to change things as you still see, tried to get it his way.
"Certain players for certain positions, for a certain style of play, that's how he sees success. He has to change a lot because the players were not used to that system.
"Also, historically, United always liked a different system. And yeah, he's been very honest and also, yeah, honest with me from the beginning. Very, very, very honest, I would say."

headline: Coleen Rooney's brutal snub summed up her feelings on husband Wayne's growing crisis
body: The life of a football manager can be a lonely one, especially when the threat of the sack looms large. So Wayne Rooney might have been forgiven for feeling somewhat abandoned when his wife, Coleen, was nowhere to be seen as he faced the axe at Plymouth this time last year.

It was almost exactly one year ago this Sunday that Rooney coached the Pilgrims for the last time. The Devon outfit travelled to Oxford on December 29, 2024, in desperate need of points to improve their Championship relegation odds against a rival in similar circumstances.
Many managers might expect to turn around and see a few familiar faces in the crowd for moral support on such occasions. And yet Coleen was nowhere to be seen during Rooney's make-or-break moment.

Instead, she was taking in some festive football at Goodison Park, where she watched her local team take on Nottingham Forest instead. Rooney's better half posted a picture from the directors' lounge on Merseyside, almost 300 miles from her hubby.

In the end, it proved to be the final nail in the coffin for Manchester United legend Rooney. A 2-0 loss at Oxford ended up being his last test as Plymouth chief, and he promptly left the club just two days later.

He departed Home Park with five wins and 14 losses from 25 games in charge. And though not as bad as his stint with Birmingham City, he nonetheless departed Plymouth having failed to build any more credibility as a coach.

Any legacy was only damaged further when his successor, Miron Muslic, did a superior job in his five months as a replacement. The Austrian even suggested Plymouth would have survived had he been appointed sooner.

It was always established that Coleen wouldn't be moving with Wayne to the south coast. Stability for their four young sons remained the priority, though she acknowledged the long-term setup was nothing compared to his time as coach of DC United.

"We see him a couple of times a week, which is good," Coleen told the Sunday Mirror in September 2024. "He went to America, so this is a bonus because even though it seems like far away, it's easier to get to than Washington, DC."

She continued: "We thought long and hard about it (moving to Devon) but with the kids it didn’t work. Kai’s now in Year 10 and just starting GCSE prep, and everything’s going well with football, and the other boys are all settled at school.

"So it didn’t seem fair on the children to pick them up and take them away, and start in a whole new place. It’s manageable. It’s life. Other couples and families have similar situations and have to get on with it."

One year on from his Plymouth departure, there's no sign of a new coaching position on the horizon for Rooney. However, he may have to pick a position closer to home if he expects his adoring wife to be on hand for the big occasions.

headline: Wayne Rooney issues Man Utd transfer demand as he makes Ruben Amorim expectations clear
body: United manager Ruben Amorim was without Bruno Fernandes, Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt for the game, while Mason Mount also went off injured. Meanwhile, Bryan Mbeumo, Amad Diallo and Noussair Mazraoui are away at the Africa Cup of Nations.

Amorim switched to a back four and was rewarded when Patrick Dorgu scored his first goal for the club. The United boss also used academy graduates Jack Fletcher and Tyler Fredricson off the substitutes’ bench, which also contained fellow youngsters Tyler Fletcher, Shea Lacey and Bendito Mantato.

United legend Rooney was happy to see his former side hang on and claim three points, which left them sixth in the Premier League, and academy players given a chance to impress, but couldn’t hide his overall feelings. “I was worried when I saw the performance, if I’m being honest,” Rooney said on Match of the Day.

“The manager changed the formation and he went with a back four, which a lot of people have been asking for. I know they didn’t concede a goal but they didn’t really look comfortable and Newcastle put them under pressure, especially in the second half.
“And when I look at the squad and the bench, what they’ve got there, they really need players in to try and help them to challenge and get into the top four.

“It’s great to see the young players on the bench and getting that opportunity, but it needs to be at the right time as well. It’s not sustainable at all. They need players in. They’ve obviously lost some important players and Bruno is a big loss.

“They had 33 per cent possession in the Newcastle game – and I know when those fans go to Old Trafford they want to see the team with the ball, they want to see them entertaining, getting crosses into the box and getting shots off. It was a poor performance, but they found a way to win.”

United are understood to be chasing a midfielder in the January transfer window, with Everton’s James Garner and Atletico Madrid’s Conor Gallagher among the targets. The club have previously considered Crystal Palace’s Adam Wharton and Brighton’s Carlos Baleba after spending £200million in the summer transfer window to bolster their attack.

Amorim has already ruled out panic-buying in January after losing captain Fernandes to injury. “What we cannot do is to reach January and try to do everything in urgency and make mistakes and then [it’s] ‘here we go again’ with a lot of mistakes,” Amorim said last week.
“I’m not going to get [together] with [club chiefs] Jason [Wilcox] and Omar [Berrada] and say: ‘We need a lot of players.’ Because we have a plan.

“If we have to suffer, the club comes first. Of course, we are in a moment where we need points but we need to find solutions and we are going to continue with our plan. You can feel in this moment that we are going to struggle, but we will see. We have to deal with it.”

headline: Sir Alex Ferguson's thoughts on Kobbie Mainoo are clear after Scott McTominay comments
body: Sir Alex Ferguson believes academy players are still the future of Manchester United despite the likes of Scott McTominay and Alejandro Garnacho being sold. Both former Carrington stars have left the club in the last year with fellow academy boy Kobbie Mainoo potentially following suit in January.

McTominay graduated from the United youth team in 2013, working his way up the ranks until he made his senior debut in 2017. The Scottish midfielder made 255 appearances for the club, scoring 29 goals and providing eight assists before moving on to Napoli in 2024.
Former manager Ferguson was full of praise for McTominay during his time at the club. He insisted the playmaker would go on to become one of United's biggest stars.

"Scott McTominay is now emerging as one of Man United's big players," Ferguson told the Scottish FA in 2021. "When you watch Man United pick their team for a big game, McTominay's name is in it. He's a good character, a great trainer. I know a little bit about the boy and I think that's the background."
Just three years later, McTominay left United and became Italy's newest hero as he helped Napoli win the Serie A title at the first time of asking.

Now, fellow midfielder Mainoo may be following in his former teammate's footsteps and Fergie will likely be left saddened by this. Speaking at a golf event in 2024, the iconic manager insisted that the likes of Mainoo and Garnacho - who is now at Chelsea - are the beating soul of the club.

Ferguson said: "It's the foundation isn’t it? It's the heart and soul of what Manchester United has been since the days of Sir Matt Busby, who started the whole process of trusting young players playing.
"They're young. What they’re showing at the moment, the composure and confidence to play in the first-team, and not be daunted by it. In a way, it shows you the kind of courage they have."
Ferguson's thoughts are clear on the sale of Mainoo from these comments - sell him and you are losing the true meaning of Manchester United.

Despite rumours circling that the England international is set to leave Old Trafford, current boss Ruben Amorim claims he isn't the one who wants to see Mainoo go. Speaking before United's 1-0 win over Newcastle on Boxing Day, the Portuguese boss insists the midfielder will not leave.
Amorim said: "Kobbie Mainoo will have the opportunity he has all the time. He played in different positions - we talked about the position of Casemiro, he can do that.

"If you play with a three, he can play like we did in the last game with the position of Mason Mount, he can play there. He is going to be the future of Manchester United, that is my feeling, he just needs to wait for his chance and everything can change in football in two days."
Reflecting on United's depth in midfield, the 40-year-old added: "If we are not getting someone, it’s hard to [let Mainoo leave]. We are shorter.

"Even with a full squad, we are shorter with something that can happen here. We are a club with a big responsibility. We are dealing with all these issues and in everybody’s head, we need to win every game, there are no excuses. So it’s going to be hard to leave the club if we don’t get a substitution.
"A few days before [his injury], we were talking about Kobbie doesn’t have the minutes he deserves or needs. Then there’s an opportunity, and Kobbie is not there.
"Sometimes, it is bad luck and during this year, we have some moments with a bit of bad luck."

headline: Man Utd news: Ruben Amorim given January transfer dilemma as signing speaks out
body: Manchester United are preparing for a crucial period on and off the pitch. The Red Devils secured a hard-fought 1-0 win over Newcastle United on Boxing Day and another three points over Wolves on Tuesday would end a tough year on a high note.

Ruben Amorim must have wondered whether he would see in 2026 as United boss at one stage, as the team lurched from one disaster to another at the start of the season. However, the Portuguese coach has steadied the ship, with United looking in better shape than 12 months ago.
Next year could be another one of change at Old Trafford, with the futures of numerous players up in the air. With the transfer window looming, here's a round-up of the latest United news…
Roma have submitted an official offer to sign striker Joshua Zirkzee, according to various reports. The Rome club are said to have tabled a loan bid with an obligation to buy.

However, while the Dutchman is evidently not in Amorim's long-term plans, the coach must consider whether he would be prepared to let him go as early as next month, given Bryan Mbeumo and Amad Diallo are away at the Africa Cup of Nations.

While a loan offer is believed to have been received, United are said to be taking their time to mull over their options before making a firm decision on Zirkzee's future. The 24-year-old came off the bench against Newcastle but struggled to get into the game as United tried to protect their lead.

Mbeumo of Cameroon and the Ivory Coast's Amad are due to meet in a group match on Sunday, having won their opening games. It's entirely possible that both countries could go deep into the tournament, ruling them out of United action until late January, leaving Amorim and United with a tricky decision to make.
Incoming signing Cristian Orozco has described moving to United as a dream come true. The Colombian teenager is due to join the club when he turns 18 in July.

The Red Devils have cast their net far and wide as they seek to build for both the present and the future. They signed 18-year-old Diego Leon from Paraguayan side Cerro Porteno earlier this year and have since moved for Orozco.

The 17-year-old midfielder plays for Fortaleza CEIF in his homeland and captained Colombia U17s to the South American Championship final in April. The youngster recently visited Manchester and was impressed with what he saw.

He said: "It went really well, to be honest. I was looking around the city. Everything was beautiful. I was able to see the facilities, the stadium. I'm truly fulfilling a childhood dream. It was a wonderful experience.

"My expectation right now is to learn English a lot. I realised it’s very important. I want to arrive, learn, and adapt as quickly as possible. That’s what’s required to demonstrate my level there, what I can do.
"I know that with my abilities, I can be key, with the strength and technique I have. I’m very young and I need to adapt."

headline: Kobbie Mainoo faces stark Man Utd warning as Ruben Amorim's true feelings questioned
body: Kobbie Mainoo has been served a harsh dose of reality as speculation continues around his Manchester United future. The 20-year-old has become one of Old Trafford's most discussed figures this season, despite barely featuring on the pitch.

Mainoo hasn't been given a single Premier League start under Ruben Amorim this term and has only started once across all competitions in a shocking Carabao Cup exit to League Two outfit Grimsby Town back in August. Despite his limited game time, the England international continues to attract attention from European giants Napoli and Bayern Munich, who are reportedly keeping tabs on his situation.

Mainoo even sought a loan switch late in the summer transfer window, raising doubts about his standing in Amorim's plans. The Portuguese manager insisted this week that the youngster remains integral to his vision for the club, even branding him the "future of Manchester United".
But former Premier League striker Dean Saunders believes the hype around Mainoo has spiralled beyond what he's actually achieved, whilst questioning whether Amorim truly means what he says.

Speaking on talkSPORT, the ex-Wolves and Wrexham boss said: "I've never known a player get so much airtime and so much press without kicking a ball. He's in the back pages of the paper every day. Mainoo this, Mainoo that and he hasn't started since Grimsby away in the cup when they got knocked out.

"They were horrendous against Grimsby and I think sometimes, as a manager, you watch that game and you think, 'that's it, he's never playing again. He [Amorim] has played Fernandes in that role with Casimero and he [Mainoo] has not got the chance to play.

"It won't go on forever, because he's played for England and he's shown his potential. He scored a couple of good goals, but I don't think he does know that position. He [Amorim] has just gone, 'I've had enough of this every day. Mainoo this, Mainoo that. I'll put it to bed by just saying he's not going anywhere.'".
The harsh assessment stands in stark contrast to Amorim's public support, after the United manager dismissed any talk of a January departure.
He said: "He's going to be the future of Manchester United, that is my feeling. He just needs to wait for his chance and everything can change in football in two days.

"Kobbie Mainoo will have the opportunity he has all the time. He played in different positions; he can do that [defensive midfield] position, he can play if we play with three, he can play like we play in the last game - the position of Mason Mount in this game [against Villa]."

Amorim subsequently dismissed speculation about Mainoo departing Old Trafford next month, saying: "If we are not getting someone, it is hard to leave. Even with a full squad we are shorter [in terms of players] for something that can happen here so it's going to be hard for someone to leave the club if we don't get a substitution."

However, despite being recently sidelined with a calf injury, there are ongoing queries about why Mainoo hasn't been able to secure a spot in Amorim's starting line-up. Saunders suggests that a short-term loan move overseas could be beneficial for the midfielder, identifying Italy as an ideal place for development.

He added: "He's shown potential, but this is Man United we're talking about. They're trying to win everything they enter. They're a massive club and in that number six position, you have to smell danger from all angles.
"I think, for a young lad to learn that, it's difficult unless he's playing every week. I think you're doing good if you go to Napoli or somewhere like that, one of these Italian teams."

headline: Man Utd handed new referee verdict after Lisandro Martinez flashpoint vs Newcastle
body: Ex-Premier League referee Keith Hackett has backed Anthony Taylor's decision not to award Newcastle a penalty for a handball by Manchester United captain Lisandro Martinez.

During the match on Boxing Day, a shot from Fabian Schar hit the stand-in United captain inside the six-yard box. Despite Martinez's claims to referee Taylor, that the ball had struck him in the stomach, replays suggested his arm had made contact with the ball.

Video assistant referee Stuart Attwell reviewed that incident, but decided against any further action. Hackett, who previously served as the general manager of Professional Game Match Officials Limited (PGMOL), has now given his verdict on the contentious decision.

Speaking to Football Insider, Hackett said: "The referee has to judge if the action by the player is deliberate when deciding that an offence has taken place, not every time the ball comes into contact, is it an offence. There is sufficient doubt in this action not to award a penalty kick."
"Schar hits it, his arm is up above his head, and it's stretched. Is it because he's pushing [Malick] Thiaw?
"That might just save him. He's actually wrestling with the other Newcastle centre-back; his arms are already there.
"If Thiaw is nowhere near him, then that's definitely a penalty. I think the fact that he has just had a wrestle with the other centre-back might just save him."

Neville also revealed what the VAR officials made of the controversial moment. The pundit added: "He's saying the context is because there's another situation whereby he's fighting with another player, and his arm's are already up there and he's just not got back down."
Main commentator Peter Drury explained: "They are calling it mutual contact between Martinez and Thiaw. And that's essentially the explanation for the fact that there won't be a penalty."

Following United's triumph, head coach Ruben Amorim heaped praise on Martinez. He said: "I think he's a guy with a lot of character. He's really good on the ball, and that came with the quality that he has.

"He played [in the] World Cup, he won [the] World Cup. He's used to that stress, and he showed today that he's a top player, and sometimes people talk about the way he defends the box because he's a small guy, but today he did really well against a team that just has tall players."

Yet when he was in turn pressed on whether the squad would be stronger with Martinez maintaining his fitness, Amorim declined to single out individuals. He responded: "No, I don't want to say that because - if we don't have more points - it's because of the team, not because of a specific player."

headline: Marcus Rashford's decision on January transfer says it all about Man Utd exile's character
body: Much has changed in the 12 months since Marcus Rashford first signalled that he wanted to move on from Manchester United. The 28-year-old is currently experiencing something of a career revival with Barcelona, but his outlook once appeared far less encouraging after a breakdown in his relationship with United head coach Ruben Amorim.

Following 18 months of poor form and with Amorim determined to shape his team around a strong, central No. 9, Rashford found himself at a crossroads. Despite being born and raised in Manchester, Rashford had carried ambitions that stretched beyond Old Trafford.
Barcelona was always his dream move abroad. However, getting to the Camp Nou was never going to come easily and demanded both patience and resilience.

When the January transfer window opened, talks with the Catalan giants took place, but a deal was never reached. Instead, Rashford sealed a loan switch to Aston Villa on deadline day, viewing it as a chance to rebuild his damaged standing.

He managed just four goals in 17 games at Villa Park, yet his overall contribution in the West Midlands proved sufficient to reignite Barcelona's interest later that summer. "I just believe that things happen when they're supposed to happen," Rashford told ESPN in October.

"It's not the first time I spoke with Barcelona about potentially coming here, but for whatever reasons it didn't happen in the past and now is my opportunity to make it happen. I feel like there's no time like the present now. So I just take things day to day.

"The key thing for me is just to continue to improve because when you retire, you're going to miss everything - the good stuff, the bad stuff - you're going to miss it about the sport. Every day I just take it day by day and just try to improve from the day before."

Those comments underline Rashford's mindset - an aspect of his career that was often examined closely during his spell at United. The England forward frequently faced criticism for his conduct on and off the field, but a renewed sense of purpose and a quieter dedication to his work appear to have transformed perceptions and produced clear results.

"I was clear on my preference from the beginning," Rashford explained after completing his move to Barcelona in July. "It didn't work out in January so I went to Aston Villa and enjoyed a good period there. I'm very grateful for the opportunity to play there.
"The summer came around very quickly, it was time to make another decision. My choice was easy."

Life at Barcelona has suited Rashford well so far. He has established himself as a near constant presence in Hansi Flick's line-up, sitting out just one of Barcelona's 25 fixtures across all competitions to date.

Statistics back up his importance. Rashford has delivered nine goals and 11 assists, with his influence especially evident in the Champions League, where he has been directly involved in seven goals in six matches.

That resurgence has also helped him reclaim a regular role with England. As Barcelona are widely expected to make his loan deal permanent next year, Rashford's call to leave last January - no matter where he landed - looks increasingly astute.

headline: Ruben Amorim faces nervous Man Utd wait during next game after triple AFCON blow
body: Patrick Dorgu will have to be on his best behaviour against Wolves next week if he wants to avoid a suspension. The full-back, who scored the winner in the 1-0 clash with Newcastle United on Boxing Day, is currently walking a tightrope.

The 21-year-old has totted-up four yellow cards this season after 18 games. Collecting five before reaching the 19-match threshold of a campaign triggers an automatic one-match ban for any Premier League player.

This means Dorgu - and his manager for that matter - face a tense 90 minutes against Wolves in their next fixture, with three teammates unavailable due to the Africa Cup Of Nations and Bruno Fernandes amongst those still side-lined through injury.

After being dropped and openly criticised by Ruben Amorim just a few weeks earlier, Dorgu has forced his way back into their starting XI with an assist (vs Aston Villa) and goal (vs Newcastle), helping United feel significantly more secure despite their depleted squad.

"He needs to be calmer playing the game," Amorim said during a press conference when asked about what Dorgu needs to work on, adding: "You can feel the anxiety every time Patrick touches the ball. I can feel the anxiety."

After that press conference, Dorgu was dropped from the United starting line-up. He was subsequently named among the substitutes for the following five fixtures, before then being brought back into the fold against Villa.

Speaking to reporters after the final whistle against Newcastle, Dorgu addressed how he's handled recent criticism. He said: "Of course, it's never nice to get criticism, but you will always get it as a player.
"And you need to react well to it, and I think I've reacted well in the last couple of games."
He added: "The manager spoke about my confidence a few weeks ago. I just looked inside and tried to understand what he meant. And I just tried to build myself up."

Now perhaps a guaranteed starter for the Wolves clash on December 30, Dorgu has carved out a fresh role in the revamped line-up. But one mistake against the bottom-placed team will see the Denmark international suspended for a crucial trip to Leeds United.
Amorim will be desperate to have the ex-Lecce man available for the journey to Elland Road. A few weeks back, however, he might not have anticipated relying on him so heavily.

Brought back into the fold out of necessity due to three teammates being away at AFCON, Dorgu has, on initial evidence, seized his opportunity. The last thing he'll want now is to lose his grip on the starting place and hand a similar chance to another squad member under Amorim.

Dorgu arrived at the club courtesy of Amorim during last season's January transfer window, with United paying £30million for his services. In his time wearing United's colours, the wing-back has racked up 38 appearances.

His strike against Newcastle marked his maiden goal for the club, complementing his three assists along the way. Dorgu, who has earned 12 senior caps for Denmark, is also tied to Old Trafford until 2030.

headline: Roy Keane and Gary Neville agree after Ruben Amorim FINALLY makes key Man Utd change
body: Ayden Heaven was showered with praise after earning the man of the match award in Manchester United’s backs-to-the-wall win over Newcastle on Boxing Day. Heaven is just 19 years old and was making just his 13th appearance for the club in a new position, but shone at Old Trafford.

United were without Bruno Fernandes, Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt for the game, while Mason Mount also went off injured. Meanwhile, Bryan Mbeumo, Amad Diallo and Noussair Mazraoui are away at the Africa Cup of Nations, forcing Ruben Amorim to adapt.

The home side took the lead through Patrick Dorgu’s stunning volley from a Diogo Dalot long throw-in and then managed to weather the storm of Newcastle pressure. Key to their victory was the performance of Heaven, who slotted in at right centre-back, despite being left-footed.

Amorim has been stubborn in his use of a 3-4-2-1 formation since becoming United boss, but did adapt against Newcastle, with a rare back four often resembling a back six in the latter stages of the match. It helped United keep just their second clean sheet of the season and their first since a 2-0 win over Sunderland on October 4.

Former United defender Gary Neville added: “Manchester United hung in there. Heaven was absolutely brilliant. Those Newcastle players… four or five of them collapsed to the ground at the end. Heaven has been the man of the match.”

“This guy (Dorgu) here helped us get there, so thankful to everyone that helped us. It was different, I was playing on the right side, obviously my weaker foot. The manager, we play loads of formations with him, whatever he does we know it’s going to work, you saw today. I’m so proud of the team.”

Amorim praised his players for toughing out the win despite seeing little of the ball and was particularly happy with his young defender. “I'm really pleased with Ayden. You can feel that he’s improving every game,” he said. “He's young, but you don't feel that he has a good game and then he slows the game or the thinking during the game.

“No, you feel that he’s improving during the game. I think he was not playing, but he trained really well. You just need to train really well to be ready when the opportunity comes. So, in this moment, if you continue to play like that, it's going to be really hard to take his place.”

headline: Ruben Amorim's dilemma is obvious as Man Utd fans make feelings crystal clear
body: It's been a tough year for Manchester United fans. The Red Devils finished 15th - their worst position in Premier League history - lost a European final and failed to win a domestic trophy.

Ruben Amorim's credentials are still being questioned on a weekly basis, and on paper, many would argue that he's in charge of the weakest United squad of the post-Sir Alex Ferguson era. That's despite another injection of £215million over the summer.
One player who's still shining, however, is Bruno Fernandes. That is until he got injured.

Red Devils captain Fernandes went off at half-time with a hamstring problem during last Sunday's toothless 2-1 loss away to Aston Villa. His absence was immediately felt, as United showed little goal threat.

It was the same during their Boxing Day victory over Newcastle. Although Patrick Dorgu's strike gave them a 1-0 home win, Newcastle fired off six more shots and had treble the amount of touches in the opposition box.
Matthijs de Ligt came third with 36 votes while Casemiro earned 28. In fifth place, Harry Maguire got 19 - likely thanks to that special moment at Anfield.

The gulf between Fernandes and his team-mates is undeniable and Amorim must find a solution when he's missing. That's not just for this season either, as the 31-year-old has left the door open to a departure from Old Trafford next summer.
As for when he'll return from his injury, Amorim said earlier this week: "I don't want to say. I have an idea but let's see."

The United boss even told his players that Fernandes was 'impossible to replace'. "I said that this morning to the team," Amorim revealed. "We need to take the good thing - if there is a good thing on that - that a lot of people need to step up and understand we cannot rely on one player for everything.

"Sometimes we rely on Bruno for organisation and the creation. We have lost Bruno on set-pieces, Bryan [Mbeumo] and Amad on set-pieces, so this is massive for the team. But it is an opportunity for other players to step up and show the leadership that we need in the team."

headline: Ayden Heaven's Premier League ambitions speak volumes about Ruben Amorim at Man Utd
body: Ayden Heaven believes Manchester United could 'possibly push' to claim the Premier League title this season following their Boxing Day triumph over Newcastle United. Heaven earned man of the match honours for his display at Old Trafford after helping the Red Devils secure a clean sheet in their victory against the Magpies.
The 19-year-old said: "It was [big]- finally a clean sheet. We've been waiting for this for a couple of weeks. I'm just so happy. I'm so thankful for everyone who helped us [win].

"As Manchester United, we belong in Europe, and we want to get back there next season. We can push for the top four, possibly push for the league; anything is possible. We are just going to keep trying.
"The manager, we play loads of formations with him, whatever he does, we know it's going to work, you saw today. I'm so proud of the team."

However, Roy Keane has suggested United are not quite prepared to challenge for the title. The club's former skipper said during Sky's match coverage: "[Heaven] mentioned there about winning titles - they're not quite ready for that, but you have to start somewhere."

Heaven has previously voiced his confidence that United will return to UEFA competitions next season. Following their 4-1 triumph over Wolverhampton Wanderers in early December, he said: "I don't think anyone can stop us when we play like this. We want to win as many games as possible. Hopefully we can be in Europe next season, which I think we'll do."

Ruben Amorim also weighed in on when United might next clinch the league title, ahead of their final match before Christmas against Aston Villa. His comments came in response to Sir Alex Ferguson saying to Press Box PR that it could take his former club a decade or more to secure their next title.
The current United head coach responded: "He understands football more, especially English football. I don't think we'll take that long to win the league.
"I don't know which manager will be here, but I truly believe we can fight for the title in the next years. It is not going to take so many years, but you never know.
"In leadership, it's the moment of the club; you have to fight all the fights. We are improving as a team.

"As a group, we are going to improve in these small things. That will make a difference even to suffer goals. If we are a different group, we will suffer less goals, but we are scoring more, so let's think about the positives."

headline: MARSHALL: A Manchester United legend and a current player have noticed the same thing about Senne Lammens
body: There were plaudits aplenty for Manchester United players on Boxing Day, particularly the defenders who had managed to dig in and preserve a backs-to-the-wall clean sheet that secured a 1-0 win against Newcastle. It was a win that temporarily moved them up to fifth and showed a different side to their game.

United had just 24% possession in the second half and had to do plenty of defending, with Ayden Heaven and Lisandro Martinez excellent. However, throughout the siege, there was a sense of calm that isn't always associated with Ruben Amorim's side, particularly when under pressure.

The return of Martinez might have helped in that regard, but 23-year-old goalkeeper Senne Lammens has also had an impact, even if his statistics aren't yet making that clear after his £18.2million move from Royal Antwerp. This was just Lammens' second clean sheet in 12 games.

His celebrations at the end showed he was desperate to get the shut-out and although he didn't have to make any outstanding saves, he was secure in goal. There was one excellent claim under a high ball in injury time that relieved the pressure and earned him a pat on the back from teammates.

It was hard to imagine United defending with the poise they did had a different goalkeeper been behind the defence. Andre Onana's form fell apart at Old Trafford and his inconsistency too often spread panic and uncertainty to his teammates. Altay Bayindir has had his moments, but has shown vulnerabilities under the high ball.

Lammens is still learning as a goalkeeper and has just 106 senior appearances to his name, with only 55 of those in Belgium's Pro League before his move to United. It was a signing based on potential, but he has faced little competition in goal, and the improvement when he plays is clearer in the way his teammates have reacted to him than in the saves he has made.
That is something one of United's greatest ever goalkeepers has noticed. Speaking before the Newcastle game, Peter Schmeichel was full of praise for Lammens.

"He's only 23 years old, he's come in and there's calm at the back four, there's not this chaos where they don't want to pass him the ball back to him. They trust him. He seems a very, very confident young man," Schmeichel told Viaplay.

"And also, one more thing I like about him is he is so quick in turning the game. So when he gets the ball, he's not afraid of kicking the ball up the other end or throwing the ball up. Starting a counter-attack very quickly.

"I don't think he pays too much attention to the results of the goals he conceded. I think he's living a dream and everyday he comes in and he wants to learn and he wants to improve and I think he's done really well."

That calmness was a trait noted by Boxing Day matchwinner Patrick Dorgu. “I think he helped with his calmness," he said. “He’s very calm and he’s talking a lot to the defenders and helping everyone on the pitch with his communication.
“He’s just calm and he tries to take responsibility to help us defenders as well. He came in well and he’s doing really well, so he just needs to keep going.”

Lammens is yet to make an error leading to a goal this season and, as Schmeichel touched on, he is happy to go long with his kicking when required. The sound of Old Trafford getting agitated as United try and fail to play out from the back has gone, with their new No.1 better at picking his moments to go short.

It hasn't been a faultless start, and Lammens would have expected to do better with a couple of Bournemouth's goals in the 4-4 draw at Old Trafford earlier this month, but he is still inexperienced for the role he is now fulfilling and there has been plenty more in the positive column in his first few months at the club.

headline: Ruben Amorim has just been handed Manchester United January transfer solution
body: Much has been made of Ruben Amorim's view of the Manchester United academy in recent days. It was only earlier this month when the United boss was having to defend his selection and reasoning behind overlooking the potential of youth.

That changed at Old Trafford on Boxing Day night with United naming five academy graduates on the bench and bringing two of them one. Tyler Fredricson was given the final few minutes as the Reds saw out a 1-0 victory while Jack Fletcher played the second half in place of the injured Mason Mount.

It was a show of faith from Amorim in Fletcher given the manager could have called upon Joshua Zirkzee to fill the second striker role. But the Dutchman was introduced off the bench, just as he had been at Villa Park a few days prior.

United had impressed in the first half with Patrick Dorgu's fine goal the difference at the interval but the Reds were forced to defend deep in the second period to see out the contest, meaning Fletcher didn't get on the ball as much as he would have liked. But after adjusting to the pace of the contest, the 18-year-old didn't look out of place in senior football.

“I think it might take a while to adjust to the tempo and intensity," said Fletcher after the game. "It was really tough out there, heavy on the legs, 45 minutes of defending, I think we did well. Hopefully, I can showcase my talent more.”

His showing will provide food for thought for United, who will be looking to strengthen their midfield given the likely departure of Casemiro at the end of the season. There are question marks over Kobbie Mainoo's long-term future while Manuel Ugarte has struggled to make his mark since arriving at Old Trafford.

Fletcher, son of former United man Darren, has a bright future ahead of him and is likely to gain more minutes over the coming weeks. He might not be ready for the rough and tumble of top flight football every week just yet, but the experiences over the next few months could mean he's ready sooner rather than later. Amorim has made a point of not promoting academy talents the sake of it, so when one does come into the fray it's all the more impressive.

"Jack did a very good job," said Amorim of Fletcher. "It's a very important moment for any kid. He's going to hear from his father. He's going to talk a lot about a lot of things, but he needs to calm down and just praise the kid because he's really humble, works really hard, and he deserves this."

headline: Manchester United star is making difficult Ruben Amorim transfer decision much easier
body: Ruben Amorim would have been under no illusions as to the challenges facing him when he took on a job the size of Manchester United just over a year ago. But he was perhaps not ready for the constant headaches he would have to deal with. The nature of United means there are very few quiet days.

At the moment, he is currently juggling several issues. An injury crisis is plaguing his team with absentees across the defence and midfield stretching the squad to the maximum. Speculation surrounding the future of Kobbie Mainoo continues to rattle on as does talk of Bruno Fernandes leaving.

This is on top of the everyday challenges of pushing this club back to the heights they once reached. But one topic which has gone under the radar in the past couple of weeks is the contract situations of Casemiro and Harry Maguire.

Both men will be free agents at the end of this season, as things stand. The Brazilian has a clause in his contract which United can utilise to extend his stay in Manchester but Maguire will need to agree to a new deal if he is to stay beyond 2026.

Maguire and Casemiro can both negotiate with overseas clubs freely from the start of January as they enter the final six months of their current deals. In his pre-Newcastle press conference on Christmas Eve, Amorim was asked by MEN Sport if any further talks had taken place with the duo over their Old Trafford deals.

"No, there is no decision, we have a lot to do," Amorim responded. "We need to understand what is going to happen in the next season because we need to understand there are European games, and what we are doing.
"So we have so much to do at this moment. We are not thinking about that. We will think just think about the next game."
He added: "I'm really happy with them, but I don't know what is going to happen, so we will see what will happen until the end of the season, what position we will be, and then we will see."
Whether more is going on behind the scenes than we know remains to be seen, but at least in the case of Maguire, the decision could be being made easier by Ayden Heaven.

The Arsenal academy graduate traded the Emirates Stadium for Old Trafford last January. A matter of weeks prior to that switch he made his first-team debut for the Gunners against Preston North End in the Carabao Cup but it was clear this would be the exception, rather than the rule.

Gabriel and William Saliba are Mikel Arteta's first choices when fit, regardless of who is coming through the academy. Clearly, Heaven felt chances would be easier to come by in Manchester and so it has proved.

In the first half of the year, he was called upon four times in the Premier League. An injury picked up against Leicester City scuppered his momentum and it was obvious this season would be a big one for him.
When he was initially brought in to cover injuries, he underwhelmed which was to be expected given he is still only 19 and he had not played much football since the injury at the King Power Stadium.

But in recent weeks, with Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt out, Heaven has impressed. Against Aston Villa he shone in the centre of the back three and again on Boxing Day, he showed maturity above his years.

The Englishman is starting to look fully at home in the defensive line and his form is beginning to alleviate the pressure surrounding Maguire. Amorim will be the first to say Maguire is more than just a competent defender, he is part of the leadership group and this cannot be understated.
However, Heaven is showing on the pitch he is capable of performing to the required level, even though he is still a teenager. He is a realistic successor to Maguire.

body: Hello and welcome to the live Manchester United blog on Sunday, December 28.
There's now just a matter of days until the January transfer window opens with clubs looking to tweak their squads with both incomings and outgoings for the second half of the season.
United have been linked with both arrivals and exits over the last few weeks. A move for Bournemouth's Antoine Semenyo now appears unlikely with the player reportedly preferring a move to Man City.

Concentration could instead be on strengthening the midfield, especially given the injury to club captain Bruno Fernandes. Carlos Baleba, Elliot Anderson and Adam Wharton are among the names to be linked.

There is talk of possible outgoings too. Roma are pushing to sign Joshua Zirkzee, while Kobbie Mainoo has been linked with Napoli. However, exits could be delayed until Bryan Mbeumo and Amad return from Africa Cup of Nations duty.
On the pitch, United are preparing for their Premier League clash against Wolves on Tuesday night. The bottom side visit Old Trafford in the 8.15pm kick-off.
Stay right here for all of the latest news and rumours throughout the day.
Manchester City are understood to be in pole position to sign Antoine Semenyo in January, but according to The Telegraph, Bournemouth are braced for a late twist which could involve Liverpool.
The release clause in his contract doesn't become active until Thursday. Liverpool haven't made any official move but Richard Hughes' time at Bournemouth could work in their favour.
Galatasaray are planning a 'strategic offer' for Manuel Ugarte in January, according to Fotomac.
A loan deal with a permanent purchase clause is what the Turkish giants want, believed to be worth around €25million. Lyon and Napoli are both keen themselves.
Barcelona head coach Hansi Flick has informed the club of his desire to make Marcus Rashford's loan move from Manchester United a permanent one in the summer.

After scoring seven goals and assisting eight this season, Rashford's move to Spain has an option to become permanent at the end of the season. SPORT have claime that Flick wants Barca to find a way of ensuring he signs for them permanently.
Ruben Amorim is reportedly keen on AS Roma's Manu Kone ahead of the January transfer window, with Caught Offside suggesting a move could happen next month.

Sources have told the outlet that United's move for Kone is seen as part of Amorim's plan to rebuild his midfield. Roma have ruled out a move in January, though a summer exit hasn't been put of the question.
Man United have reportedly opened talks with Auxerre striker Lassine Sinayoko over a January move.
Africa Foot have claimed that United are keen to sign the forward on a free contract when his deal in France expires at the end of the season. He has scored 25 goals in 149 games for the club.
He is currently representing Mali at AFCON and has scored in both of their opening two games.
Despite being used more by Ruben Amorim in recent weeks, Joshua Zirkzee has reportedly given his green light to move to Roma in January.

La Gazzetta dello Sport have reported that the striker has said yes to a move to the Serie A side. It's said they have tabled a £35million proposal for the forward and have held positive discussions with the Roma hierarchy and head coach Gian Piero Gasperini.
Manchester United are one of the clubs showing strong interest in AZ Alkmaar's highly rated midfielder, Kees Smit.
According to The Athletic, the 19-year-old won't be allowed to leave in January, but a summer move, close to €60m, is expected at the end of the season.
Real Madrid, Newcastle, Borussia Dortmund and Barcelona are also interested.

Manchester could face a double transfer hijack from Sunderland, according to reports.
TEAMtalk claim that the Black Cats are eyeing ambitious moves for Lille Star Ayyoub Bouaddi and Monaco's Lamine Camara.
Both players have been linked with a move to United over the last few weeks, with the two players highly rated at their respective clubs.

Former Manchester United midfielder Christian Eriksen has revealed the dressing room reaction to Ruben Amorim's claims that last season's side was the "worst in history". The Denmark international admitted that the comments from the Portuguese head coach didn't help the squad.

The former Sporting CP tactician made the admission in January following their 3-1 defeat to Brighton & Hove Albion. It was their fourth defeat in their previous five home matches and it marked a run of just 11 points since Amorim succeeded Erik ten Hag.

Manchester United linked midfielder Manu Kone has outlined his happiness at Roma.
Latest reports suggest that the Frenchman could link up with United in the summer transfer window as the club look to stregthen their midfield options.
Speaking last month, it seems that all of his concentration is on success with Roma for the rest of the season.
“Roma? I’m feeling great, we’re top of the table and I’m part of a great team.," he said.
"We hope to finish the year strong and reach the Champions League.
“We must remain humble, aware of our strengths. If we win the title, we’ll welcome it with merit.”
Manchester United defender Ayden Heaven is eligible to represent Ghana on the international stage but has reportedly chosen to not switch allegiance from England.
BBC Sport report that Heaven has been watched by the Ghana FA, but the player has ambitions to represent England at senior level.
He has previously played fot the U20s, suffering an ankle injury while on international duty back in October.
Heaven has impressed in his last two performances for United, being named as man of the match in Friday night's 1-0 win over Newcastle United.
Wolves have been handed a blow ahead of Tuesday night's clash at Old Trafford, with midfielder Andre suspended for the match.
The player picked up his fifth yellow card of the season during the defeat against Liverpool. It means that he will serve his one-match suspension against United.
Wolves have had a season to forget so far, and sit at the bottom of the table with just two points. They are yet to taste victory so far this campaign.
United legend Wayne Rooney has sent a clear message to the club ahead of the January transfer window, with the former striker hoping that they can strengthen the squad over the next month.
Speaking on Match of the Day, he said:
“I was worried when I saw the performance (vs Newcastle), if I’m being honest.

“The manager changed the formation and he went with a back four, which a lot of people have been asking for. I know they didn’t concede a goal but they didn’t really look comfortable and Newcastle put them under pressure, especially in the second half.
“And when I look at the squad and the bench, what they’ve got there, they really need players in to try and help them to challenge and get into the top four.

“It’s great to see the young players on the bench and getting that opportunity, but it needs to be at the right time as well. It’s not sustainable at all. They need players in. They’ve obviously lost some important players and Bruno is a big loss."
Bruno Fernandes may have played his final game for Manchester United, according to Football Insider.

The former Tottenham man spent three seasons at Old Trafford before leaving at the end of his contract in the summer, joining German side Wolfsburg.
Speaking in an interview with the Times. he said:

“The main thing at United is just the perception of how you have to play and how you have to be as a player, because everything you do is compared to who was there before,” Eriksen says. “So any position, you’ll be like, ‘Oh yeah, now we have Casemiro but you have to compare him to Roy Keane,’ or, ‘We had [Robin] van Persie here, so this striker now has to be able to do this.’

AS Roma midfielder Manu Kone will join Manchester United in the summer, according to journalist Francesca Teodori.

headline: RAILSTON: United defender Patrick Dorgu responds to Ruben Amorim criticism - 'Never nice'
body: Manchester United defender Patrick Dorgu believes he has responded to Ruben Amorim's criticism with his recent performances. At the end of November, Amorim said he could feel "anxiety" from Dorgu when he picked up the ball, and suggested the Denmark international needed to perform better.
"He needs to be calmer playing the game," said Amorim to a question about what Dorgu needs to improve. "You can feel the anxiety every time Patrick touches the ball. I can feel the anxiety."
Following that press conference, Dorgu lost his starting place. He was named on the bench for the next five matches, but he was recalled to the starting team against Aston Villa last weekend.

The 21-year-old assisted Matheus Cunha for United's goal in the Midlands and delivered another improved performance against Newcastle, scoring in the first half with a brilliant volley to claim three points for United.

Dorgu spoke to reporters following the full-time whistle and was asked how he dealt with the criticism. "Of course it's never nice to get criticism, but you will always get it as a player," he said. "And you need to react well to it, and I think I've reacted well in the last couple of games."
He added: "The manager spoke about my confidence a few weeks ago, so I just looked inside and tried to understand what he meant. And I just tried to build myself up."

Dorgu sought advice from the leadership group in the dressing room, which includes Bruno Fernandes, Diogo Dalot, Noussair Mazraoui, Lisandro Martinez, Harry Maguire and Tom Heaton. "My teammates help me as well," he added. I spoke to Bruno [Fernandes] and some of the leader group in my team. They just try to help me on a daily basis to grow in confidence in training and stuff. "

Dorgu continued: "We have players at AFCON and injured players, so this is my chance to show I belong in this team, and I feel like I'm doing it in the last couple of games, so I just need to keep going and try to keep the manager happy."

Dorgu played on the right, in a more prominent position, against Newcastle. "I've done that in my old team as well, so it's nothing new to me. I'm just happy to score the goal," he said. "I've been training to shoot more in the games and I think I hit it really well. I'm really happy that it went in. I knew already a few days ago [about playing on the right], so I just tried to remember how to play there.
"It's the same, just you come inside to your stronger foot, so sometimes it's even easier to attack and connect with the teammates, so I find it really easy."

headline: Rasmus Hojlund Napoli verdict speaks volumes as Man United striker sends five-word message
body: Rasmus Hojlund was on the scoresheet once again for Napoli this weekend as the Manchester United loanee continued to showcase his ability in front of goal this season.

The striker scored both goals as the Italian champions defeated Cremonese on Sunday, in his latest statement for the Naples-based side. He has now scored seven goals in 19 appearances this season, just three less than the ten he managed for United last term.

Hojlund moved to italy on a season-long loan on deadline day after United opted to spend big on Benjamin Sesko. The deal includes an obligation for Napoli sign the Denmark international on a permanent deal if they qualify for the Champions League.
Following the win in Cremona, Hojlund took to Instagram to post a message to his fans. Posing with the Serie A Man of the Match trophy, he wrote: "Christmas came late this year."

Bryan Mbeumo, Patrick Dorgu, Andre Onana and Ethan Wheatley were among the thousands who liked the striker's post within the first hour. Napoli boss Antonio Conte went on to praise his striker following the win, in comments that spoke volumes about the player's standing in his side: "Hojlund is a player who, first of all, is very young, but above all, has a lot of room for improvement.
"He's becoming a dominant player in that position. He's very connected to the team. In my style of football, everyone knows that strikers have a very important and unique role.

"The road to success? Annibale said that there isn't a road, it has to be built. We are doing it despite the great difficulties." He added: "We're celebrating a wonderful year where we achieved something extraordinary and unexpected.

"We crowned the Scudetto with the Super Cup, where we beat Milan and Bologna. It was a wonderful year, full of emotions. Napoli, when you win, makes you celebrate in a different way. We're up there in the league and we're trying to stay close to the top spots. This season, we're facing several challenges, and we're always facing them with courage."

Hojlund form comes amid doubts about United's current attacking options. Sesko has managed just two goals since his move from RB Leipzig, and Joshua Zirkzee has been tipped to secure a return to Italy in January.

However, Amorim has admitted that a move for any of his players next month will only be completed if they can bring in a replacement. "It's going to be hard for someone to leave the club if we don't get a substitution," he said.

"We are a club with a big responsibility. We are dealing with all these issues and in [the media's] heads, in my head, in everybody's head, we need to win every game. It doesn't matter. There are no excuses."
